title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: HW0
text:
Introduction and Getting Started
Today, we’re going to use python to construct an interesting data visualization of the Palmer Penguins dataset. You can read the data into python by running the following code:

import pandas as pd
url = "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pic16b-ucla/24W/main/datasets/palmer_penguins.csv"
penguins = pd.read_csv(url)

Additionally, we’re going to want to import both seaborn and matplotlib to create our plots. To do this, run the following code.

import seaborn as sns 
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
import numpy as np



Analyzing the Dataset
Now let’s take a look at the dataset. To get an idea of what it looks like, let’s inspect the first five rows of our penguins DataFrame, using the .head() function as seen below.

penguins.head(5)

As we can see, the data holds recorded measurements of Culmen length and depth, flipper length, and body mass, with indentifiers such as the study name, sample number, species, region, island, stage, individual id, clutch completion, egg date, and sex. In all, there 17 columns for each entry.


Visualizing the Correlations in the Dataset
Let’s try and find a correlation between measurements. Take flipper length and body mass. An interesting hypothesis would be that as flipper length increases, so does body mass. Let’s visualize this using a scatterplot. We’ll use seaborn and matplotlib along with the “penguins” dataframe we made earlier. The code is as follows:

sns.scatterplot(data=penguins, x="Flipper Length (mm)", y="Body Mass (g)")
plt.title("Penguin Flipper Length Affect On Body Mass")
plt.show








We take data from our penguins DataFrame, specifically from the “Flipper Length (mm)” and “Body Mass (g)” columns. We use seaborn as a shortcut to using matplotlib functions, like scatterplot as above. Pass penguins, “Flipper Length (mm),” and “Body Mass (g)” as arguments to sns.scatterplot. Choose a preferred title, and plot using plt.show. As a further modification, we can add a line of best fit by using sns.regplot, which autofits a line of regression. It’s produced as follows:

sns.regplot(data=penguins, x="Flipper Length (mm)", y="Body Mass (g)", scatter_kws={"color":"blue"}, line_kws={"color":"red"})
plt.title("Penguin Flipper Length Affect On Body Mass")
plt.show








Here, scatter_kws and line_kws are both dictionaries that allow us to change the colors of the datapoints and line of best fit. Body mass and flipper length seem to be directly proportional. This makes sense, since the larger the flipper, the heavier it is, thus increasing body mass.
